tn.text: Here "he fought" means that his army fought. AT: "his army fought against Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the people of Israel. AT: "The people of Israel vowed" or "The Israelites made a vow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "listen" means that Yahweh did as they asked. AT: "did what Israel asked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "voice" is a metonym that refers to their request. AT: "what Israel asked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They completely destroyed them and their cities
tn.text: "The people of Israel completely destroyed the Canaanite army and their cities"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "They called that place Hormah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness?
tn.text: The people used this question in order to rebuke Moses. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not made us leave Egypt to die in the wilderness!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: we have spoken against Yahweh and you
tn.text: "we have said bad things about Yahweh and you"
The word "we" here refers to the people but not to Yahweh or Moses. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

Since it is impossible for Moses to make a real snake, it is implied that he was to make a model of a snake. This implied information can be made clear. AT: "Make a model of a snake" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "everyone whom a snake bites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"a snake out of bronze"

tn.ref: if he looked at the bronze snake, he survived
tn.text: Here "he" refers to "any person" who was bitten by a snake.
Here "faces" is an idiom that means "is across from" or "is next to." AT: "that is next to Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: forms the border of Moab, between Moab and the Amorites
tn.text: This means that the two peoples lived on different sides of the river, which was a boundary between them. The Moabite people lived south of the river and the Amorites lived on the north.
These are both names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the slope of the valleys that lead toward the town of Ar and go down toward the border of Moab
tn.text: "downhill to the town of Ar and the border of the country of Moab"

tn.ref: to Beer, which is where the well is
tn.text: This can be stated as two sentences. AT: "to Beer. There was a well there" (UDB)

tn.ref: where Yahweh said to Moses, "Gather the people together for me to give them water."
tn.text: This can be stated as an indirect quote. AT: "where Yahweh told Moses to gather the people together for him to give them water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

Here "well" represents the water in the well. The Israelites are speaking to the water as if it were a person who could hear them, and they are asking for it to fill the well. AT: "Water, fill up the well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: The well that our leaders dug, the well the people's nobles dug
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the role of the leaders in digging the well. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: with the scepter and their staffs
tn.text: A scepter was carried by those with authority, and the staff was carried by everyone. Neither of these are digging tools. These two items emphasize that they were not too proud to use any means available. AT: "using even their scepter and staffs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a mountain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This is an idiom. It is a way of saying that the mountain is high, and speaks of the mountain as if it were a person who looks down to see the wilderness below him. AT: "rises above the wilderness" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel, and especially to their leaders. AT: "Then the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: We will not turn into any field or vineyard
tn.text: "We will not go into any of your fields or vineyards"
This is the main road that connects Damascus in the north to the Gulf of Aqabah in the south. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:20:17|20:17]].
"to cross over their border." Here "their" refers to the Amorites.
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "he" refers to King Sihon's army, and "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. AT: "his army fought against the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. AT: "The Israelites attacked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: with the edge of the sword
tn.text: "with the sharp part of the sword." The "edge of the sword" is associated with death and complete destruction. AT: "and completely defeated them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"conquered the land of the Amorites." Here the word "their" refers to the Amorites.

tn.ref: the people of Ammon ... the Amorites
tn.text: "the Ammonites ... the Amorites" or "the people of Ammon ... the people of Amor." These names are similar, but they refer to two different people groups.
"was strongly defended" (UDB). The Israelites did not attack the Ammonites.

tn.ref: Heshbon and all of its villages
tn.text: Here "its" is possessive to show that a relationship existed between the city of Heshbon and these nearby villages. AT: "Heshbon and the nearby villages that it controlled"

tn.ref: Sihon had taken all his land
tn.text: Here "his" refers to the king of Moab.
These are two names that refer to the same city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Let the city of Sihon be rebuilt and established again
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Let someone rebuild and establish again the city of Sihon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These two terms are very similar and emphasize that the city will be fully rebuilt. AT: "completely rebuilt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: A fire blazed from Heshbon, a flame from the city of Sihon
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that destruction will begin at Heshbon. The fire refers to a destroying army. AT: "King Sihon led a strong army from the city of Heshbon." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The army of Sihon is spoken of as if it was an animal that ate up the city of Ar. AT: "destroyed the town of Ar in the land of Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These two phrases refer to the same people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"Chemosh" was the name of the false god whom the Moabites worshiped. AT: "the people who worship Chemosh"
"He" and "his" refer to Chemosh.
Here "we" refers to the Israelites who defeated Sihon.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "We have devastated Heshbon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Heshbon ... all the way to Dibon ... all the way to Nophah ... to Medeba
tn.text: These are all places in Sihon's kingdom. This means the Israelites destroyed Sihon's entire nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"chased away"
"attacked them"

tn.ref: Do to him as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites
tn.text: The Israelites had completely destroyed Sihon. AT: "Destroy him like you destroyed Sihon king of the Amorites"
"So the army of Israel killed Og"

tn.ref: none of his people were left alive
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "all of his people were dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"they took control of his land"
